summary.long: Ecclesiastes is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Futility of futilities,” says the Preacher,
“Futility of futilities! All is futility.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What advantage does a person have in all his work
Which he does under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A generation goes and a generation comes,
But the earth remains forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Also, the sun rises and the sun sets;
And hurrying to its place it rises there again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blowing toward the south,
Then turning toward the north,
The wind continues swirling along;
And on its circular courses the wind returns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the rivers flow into the sea,
Yet the sea is not full.
To the place where the rivers flow,
There they flow again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All things are wearisome;
No one can tell it.
The eye is not satisfied with seeing,
Nor is the ear filled with hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What has been, it is what will be,
And what has been done, it is what will be done.
So there is nothing new under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is there anything of which one might say,
“See this, it is new”?
It has already existed for ages
Which were before us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no remembrance of the earlier things,
And of the later things as well, which will occur,
There will be no remembrance of them
Among those who will come later still.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I, the Preacher, have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I set my mind to seek and explore by wisdom about everything that has been done under heaven. It is a sorry task with which God has given the sons of mankind to be troubled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all the works which have been done under the sun, and behold, all is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What is crooked cannot be straightened, and what is lacking cannot be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, “Behold, I have magnified and increased wisdom more than all who were over Jerusalem before me; and my mind has observed a wealth of wisdom and knowledge.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I applied my mind to know wisdom and to know insanity and foolishness; I realized that this also is striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because in much wisdom there is much grief; and increasing knowledge results in increasing pain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, “Come now, I will test you with pleasure. So enjoy yourself.” And behold, it too was futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said of laughter, “It is senseless,” and of pleasure, “What does this accomplish?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I explored with my mind how to refresh my body with wine while my mind was guiding me wisely; and how to seize foolishness, until I could see what good there is for the sons of mankind to do under heaven for the few years of their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I enlarged my works: I built houses for myself, I planted vineyards for myself;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made gardens and parks for myself, and I planted in them all kinds of fruit trees;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made ponds of water for myself from which to irrigate a forest of growing trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I bought male and female slaves, and I had slaves born at home. I also possessed flocks and herds larger than all who preceded me in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also amassed for myself silver and gold, and the treasure of kings and provinces. I provided for myself male and female singers, and the pleasures of the sons of mankind: many concubines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I became great and increased more than all who preceded me in Jerusalem. My wisdom also stood by me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All that my eyes desired, I did not refuse them. I did not restrain my heart from any pleasure, for my heart was pleased because of all my labor; and this was my reward for all my labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I considered all my activities which my hands had done and the labor which I had exerted, and behold, all was futility and striving after wind, and there was no benefit under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I turned to consider wisdom, insanity, and foolishness; for what will the man do who will come after the king, except what has already been done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I saw that wisdom surpasses foolishness as light surpasses darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wise person’s eyes are in his head, but the fool walks in darkness. And yet I know that one and the same fate happens to both of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I said to myself, “As is the fate of the fool, it will also happen to me. Why then have I been extremely wise?” So I said to myself, “This too is futility.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there is no lasting remembrance of the wise, along with the fool, since in the coming days everything will soon be forgotten. And how the wise and the fool alike die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I hated life, for the work which had been done under the sun was unhappy to me; because everything is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I hated all the fruit of my labor for which I had labored under the sun, because I must leave it to the man who will come after me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And who knows whether he will be wise or a fool? Yet he will have control over all the fruit of my labor for which I have labored by acting wisely under the sun. This too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore I completely despaired over all the fruit of my labor for which I had labored under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When there is a person who has labored with wisdom, knowledge, and skill, and then gives his legacy to one who has not labored for it; this too is futility and a great evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what does a person get in all his labor and in his striving with which he labors under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because all his days his activity is painful and irritating; even at night his mind does not rest. This too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is nothing better for a person than to eat and drink, and show himself some good in his trouble. This too I have seen, that it is from the hand of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who can eat and who can have enjoyment without Him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For to a person who is good in His sight, He has given wisdom and knowledge and joy, while to the sinner He has given the task of gathering and collecting so that he may give to one who is good in God’s sight. This too is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an appointed time for everything. And there is a time for every matter under heaven—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to give birth and a time to die;
A time to plant and a time to uproot what is planted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to kill and a time to heal;
A time to tear down and a time to build up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to weep and a time to laugh;
A time to mourn and a time to dance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to throw stones and a time to gather stones;
A time to embrace and a time to shun embracing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to search and a time to give up as lost;
A time to keep and a time to throw away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to tear apart and a time to sew together;
A time to be silent and a time to speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A time to love and a time to hate;
A time for war and a time for peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What benefit is there for the worker from that in which he labors?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen the task which God has given the sons of mankind with which to occupy themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has made everything appropriate in its time. He has also set eternity in their heart, without the possibility that mankind will find out the work which God has done from the beginning even to the end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that there is nothing better for them than to rejoice and to do good in one’s lifetime;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: moreover, that every person who eats and drinks sees good in all his labor—this is the gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know that everything God does will remain forever; there is nothing to add to it and there is nothing to take from it. And God has so worked, that people will fear Him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That which is, is what has already been, and that which will be has already been; and God seeks what has passed by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, I have seen under the sun that in the place of justice there is wickedness and in the place of righteousness there is wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself, “God will judge the righteous and the wicked,” for a time for every matter and for every deed is there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I said to myself regarding the sons of mankind, “God is testing them in order for them to see that they are as animals, they to themselves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the fate of the sons of mankind and the fate of animals is the same. As one dies, so dies the other; indeed, they all have the same breath, and there is no advantage for mankind over animals, for all is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All go to the same place. All came from the dust and all return to the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who knows that the spirit of the sons of mankind ascends upward and the spirit of the animal descends downward to the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen that nothing is better than when a person is happy in his activities, for that is his lot. For who will bring him to see what will occur after him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I looked again at all the acts of oppression which were being done under the sun. And behold, I saw the tears of the oppressed and that they had no one to comfort them; and power was on the side of their oppressors, but they had no one to comfort them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I congratulated the dead who are already dead, more than the living who are still living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But better off than both of them is the one who has never existed, who has never seen the evil activity that is done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen that every labor and every skill which is done is the result of rivalry between a person and his neighbor. This too is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fool folds his hands and consumes his own flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One hand full of rest is better than two fists full of labor and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then I looked again at futility under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was a man without a dependent, having neither a son nor a brother, yet there was no end to all his labor. Indeed, his eyes were not satisfied with riches, and he never asked, “And for whom do I labor and deprive myself of pleasure?” This too is futility, and it is an unhappy task.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two are better than one because they have a good return for their labor;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for if either of them falls, the one will lift up his companion. But woe to the one who falls when there is not another to lift him up!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, if two lie down together they keep warm, but how can one be warm alone?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And if one can overpower him who is alone, two can resist him. A cord of three strands is not quickly torn apart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A poor yet wise youth is better than an old and foolish king who no longer knows how to receive instruction—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for he has come out of prison to become king, even though he was born poor in his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen all those living under the sun move to the side of the second youth who replaces him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is no end to all the people, to all who were before them. Even the ones who will come later will not be happy with him; for this too is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Guard your steps as you go to the house of God, and approach to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools; for they do not know that they are doing evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be quick with your mouth or impulsive in thought to bring up a matter in the presence of God. For God is in heaven and you are on the earth; therefore let your words be few.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the dream comes through much effort, and the voice of a fool through many words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you make a vow to God, do not be late in paying it; for He takes no delight in fools. Pay what you vow!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is better that you not vow, than vow and not pay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not let your speech cause you to sin, and do not say in the presence of the messenger of God that it was a mistake. Why should God be angry on account of your voice, and destroy the work of your hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For in many dreams and in many words there is futility. Rather, fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you see oppression of the poor and denial of justice and righteousness in the province, do not be shocked at the sight; for one official watches over another official, and there are higher officials over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all, a king who cultivates the field is beneficial to the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One who loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor one who loves abundance with its income. This too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When good things increase, those who consume them increase. So what is the advantage to their owners except to look at them?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sleep of the laborer is sweet, whether he eats little or much; but the full stomach of the rich person does not allow him to sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is a sickening evil which I have seen under the sun: wealth being hoarded by its owner to his detriment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When that wealth was lost through bad business and he had fathered a son, then there was nothing to support him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As he came naked from his mother’s womb, so he will return as he came. He will take nothing from the fruit of his labor that he can carry in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This also is a sickening evil: exactly as a person is born, so will he die. What then is the advantage for him who labors for the wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his life he also eats in darkness with great irritation, sickness, and anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Here is what I have seen to be good and fitting: to eat, to drink, and enjoy oneself in all one’s labor in which he labors under the sun during the few years of his life which God has given him; for this is his reward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, as for every person to whom God has given riches and wealth, He has also given him the opportunity to enjoy them and to receive his reward and rejoice in his labor; this is the gift of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For he will not often call to mind the years of his life, because God keeps him busy with the joy of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is widespread among mankind:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a person to whom God has given riches, wealth, and honor, so that his soul lacks nothing of all that he desires, yet God has not given him the opportunity to enjoy these things, but a foreigner enjoys them. This is futility and a severe affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man fathers a hundred children and lives many years, however many they may be, but his soul is not satisfied with good things and he does not even have a proper burial, then I say, “Better the miscarriage than he,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for a miscarriage comes in futility and goes into darkness; and its name is covered in darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It has not even seen the sun nor does it know it; yet it is better off than that man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even if the man lives a thousand years twice, but does not see good things—do not all go to one and the same place?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All a person’s labor is for his mouth, and yet his appetite is not satisfied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For what advantage does the wise person have over the fool? What does the poor person have, knowing how to walk before the living?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What the eyes see is better than what the soul desires. This too is futility and striving after wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever exists has already been named, and it is known what man is; for he cannot dispute with the one who is mightier than he is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there are many words which increase futility. What then is the advantage to a person?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For who knows what is good for a person during his lifetime, during the few years of his futile life? He will spend them like a shadow. For who can tell a person what will happen after him under the sun?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A good name is better than good oil,
And the day of one’s death is better than the day of one’s birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to go to a house of mourning
Than to go to a house of feasting,
Because that is the end of every person,
And the living takes it to heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sorrow is better than laughter,
For when a face is sad a heart may be happy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mind of the wise is in the house of mourning,
While the mind of fools is in the house of pleasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is better to listen to the rebuke of a wise person
Than for one to listen to the song of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For oppression makes a wise person look foolish,
And a bribe corrupts the heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The end of a matter is better than its beginning;
Patience of spirit is better than arrogance of spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not be eager in your spirit to be angry,
For anger resides in the heart of fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not say, “Why is it that the former days were better than these?”
For it is not from wisdom that you ask about this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Wisdom along with an inheritance is good,
And an advantage to those who see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For wisdom is protection just as money is protection,
But the advantage of knowledge is that wisdom keeps its possessors alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consider the work of God,
For who is able to straighten what He has bent?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On the day of prosperity be happy,
But on the day of adversity consider:
God has made the one as well as the other
So that a person will not discover anything that will come after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen everything during my lifetime of futility; there is a righteous person who perishes in his righteousness, and there is a wicked person who prolongs his life in his wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be excessively righteous, and do not be overly wise. Why should you ruin yourself?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be excessively wicked, and do not be foolish. Why should you die before your time?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is good that you grasp one thing while not letting go of the other; for one who fears God comes out with both of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wisdom strengthens a wise person more than ten rulers who are in a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, there is not a righteous person on earth who always does good and does not ever sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, do not take seriously all the words which are spoken, so that you do not hear your servant cursing you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for you know that even you have cursed others many times as well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I tested all this with wisdom, and I said, “I will be wise,” but wisdom was far from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What has been is remote and very mysterious. Who can discover it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I directed my mind to know and to investigate, and to seek wisdom and an explanation, and to know the evil of foolishness and the foolishness of insanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I discovered as more bitter than death the woman whose heart is snares and nets, whose hands are chains. One who is pleasing to God will escape from her, but the sinner will be captured by her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Behold, I have discovered this,” says the Preacher, “by adding one thing to another to find an explanation,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: which I am still seeking but have not found. I have found one man among a thousand, but I have not found a woman among all these.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, I have found only this, that God made people upright, but they have sought out many schemes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is like the wise person and who knows the meaning of a matter? A person’s wisdom illuminates his face and makes his stern face brighten up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I say, “Keep the command of the king because of the oath before God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not be in a hurry to leave him. Do not join in an evil matter, for he will do whatever he pleases.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since the word of the king is authoritative, who will say to him, “What are you doing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One who keeps a royal command experiences no trouble, for a wise heart knows the proper time and procedure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For there is a proper time and procedure for every delight, though a person’s trouble is heavy upon him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If no one knows what will happen, who can tell him when it will happen?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one has authority over the wind to restrain the wind, nor authority over the day of death; and there is no military discharge in the time of war, and evil will not save those who practice it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this I have seen, and have applied my mind to every deed that has been done under the sun at a time when one person has exercised authority over another person to his detriment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So then, I have seen the wicked buried, those who used to go in and out of the holy place, and they are soon forgotten in the city where they did such things. This too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the sentence against an evil deed is not executed quickly, therefore the hearts of the sons of mankind among them are fully given to do evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although a sinner does evil a hundred times and may lengthen his life, still I know that it will go well for those who fear God, who fear Him openly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But it will not go well for the evil person and he will not lengthen his days like a shadow, because he does not fear God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is futility which is done on the earth, that is, there are righteous people to whom it happens according to the deeds of the wicked. On the other hand, there are evil people to whom it happens according to the deeds of the righteous. I say that this too is futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I commended pleasure, for there is nothing good for a person under the sun except to eat, drink, and be joyful, and this will stand by him in his labor throughout the days of his life which God has given him under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I devoted my mind to know wisdom and to see the business which has been done on the earth (even though one should never sleep day or night),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I saw every work of God, I concluded that one cannot discover the work which has been done under the sun. Even though a person laboriously seeks, he will not discover; and even if the wise person claims to know, he cannot discover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I have taken all this to my heart, even to examine it all, that righteous people, wise people, and their deeds are in the hand of God. People do not know whether it will be love or hatred; anything awaits them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is the same for all. There is one fate for the righteous and for the wicked; for the good, for the clean and the unclean; for the person who offers a sacrifice and for the one who does not sacrifice. As the good person is, so is the sinner; the one who swears an oath is just as the one who is afraid to swear an oath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is an evil in everything that is done under the sun, that there is one fate for everyone. Furthermore, the hearts of the sons of mankind are full of evil, and insanity is in their hearts throughout their lives. Afterward they go to the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For whoever is joined to all the living, there is hope; for better a live dog, than a dead lion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the living know that they will die; but the dead do not know anything, nor do they have a reward any longer, for their memory is forgotten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed their love, their hate, and their zeal have already perished, and they will no longer have a share in all that is done under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go then, eat your bread in happiness, and drink your wine with a cheerful heart; for God has already approved your works.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See that your clothes are white all the time, and that there is no lack of oil on your head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Enjoy life with the wife whom you love all the days of your futile life which He has given you under the sun, all the days of your futility; for this is your reward in life and in your work which you have labored under the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with all your might; for there is no activity, planning, knowledge, or wisdom in Sheol where you are going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I again saw under the sun that the race is not to the swift and the battle is not to the warriors, and neither is bread to the wise nor wealth to the discerning, nor favor to the skillful; for time and chance overtake them all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For indeed, a person does not know his time: like fish that are caught in a treacherous net and birds caught in a snare, so the sons of mankind are ensnared at an evil time when it suddenly falls on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This too I saw as wisdom under the sun, and it impressed me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: there was a small city with few men in it, and a great king came to it, surrounded it, and constructed large siegeworks against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But there was found in it a poor wise man, and he saved the city by his wisdom. Yet no one remembered that poor man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So I said, “Wisdom is better than strength.” But the wisdom of the poor man is despised, and his words are ignored.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of the wise heard in calm are better than the shouting of a ruler among fools.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wisdom is better than weapons of war, but one sinner destroys much good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dead flies turn a perfumer’s oil rancid, so a little foolishness is more potent than wisdom and honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A wise person’s heart directs him toward the right, but the foolish person’s heart directs him toward the left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even when the fool walks along the road, his sense is lacking, and he demonstrates to everyone that he is a fool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the ruler’s temper rises against you, do not abandon your place, because composure puts great offenses to rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There is an evil I have seen under the sun, like a mistake that proceeds from the ruler:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: foolishness is set in many exalted places while the rich sit in humble places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have seen slaves riding on horses and princes walking like slaves on the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One who digs a pit may fall into it, and a serpent may bite one who breaks through a wall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One who quarries stones may be hurt by them, and one who splits logs may be endangered by them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the axe is dull and he does not sharpen its edge, then he must exert more strength. Wisdom has the advantage of bringing success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the serpent bites before being charmed, there is no benefit for the charmer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Words from the mouth of a wise person are gracious, while the lips of a fool consume him;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the beginning of his talking is foolishness, and the end of it is evil insanity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yet the fool multiplies words. No person knows what will happen, and who can tell him what will come after him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The labor of a fool makes him so weary that he does not even know how to go to a city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Woe to you, land whose king is a boy, and whose princes feast in the morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Blessed are you, land whose king is of nobility, and whose princes eat at the appropriate time—for strength and not for drunkenness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Through extreme laziness the rafters sag, and through idleness the house leaks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People prepare a meal for enjoyment, wine makes life joyful, and money is the answer to everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, in your bedroom do not curse a king, and in your sleeping rooms do not curse a rich person; for a bird of the sky will bring the sound, and the winged one will make your word known.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cast your bread on the surface of the waters, for you will find it after many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Divide your portion to seven, or even to eight, for you do not know what misfortune may occur on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the clouds are full, they pour out rain on the earth; and whether a tree falls toward the south or toward the north, wherever the tree falls, there it lies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One who watches the wind will not sow and one who looks at the clouds will not harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as you do not know the path of the wind, and how bones are formed in the womb of the pregnant woman, so you do not know the activity of God who makes everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sow your seed in the morning and do not be idle in the evening, for you do not know whether one or the other will succeed, or whether both of them alike will be good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The light is pleasant, and it is good for the eyes to see the sun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Indeed, if a person lives many years, let him rejoice in them all; but let him remember the days of darkness, for they will be many. Everything that is to come will be futility.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rejoice, young man, during your childhood, and let your heart be pleasant during the days of young manhood. And follow the impulses of your heart and the desires of your eyes. Yet know that God will bring you to judgment for all these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So remove sorrow from your heart and keep pain away from your body, because childhood and the prime of life are fleeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember also your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come and the years approach when you will say, “I have no pleasure in them”;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: before the sun and the light, the moon and the stars are darkened, and clouds return after the rain;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: on the day that the watchmen of the house tremble, and strong men are bent over, the grinders stop working because they are few, and those who look through windows grow dim;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the doors on the street are shut as the sound of the grinding mill is low, and one will arise at the sound of the bird, and all the daughters of song will sing softly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, people are afraid of a high place and of terrors on the road; the almond tree blossoms, the grasshopper drags itself along, and the caper berry is ineffective. For man goes to his eternal home while the mourners move around in the street.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember your Creator before the silver cord is broken and the golden bowl is crushed, the pitcher by the spring is shattered and the wheel at the cistern is crushed;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then the dust will return to the earth as it was, and the spirit will return to God who gave it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Futility of futilities,” says the Preacher, “all is futility!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition to being wise, the Preacher also taught the people knowledge; and he pondered, searched out, and arranged many proverbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Preacher sought to find delightful words and to write words of truth correctly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The words of the wise are like goads, and masters of these collections are like driven nails; they are given by one Shepherd.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But beyond this, my son, be warned: the writing of many books is endless, and excessive study is wearying to the body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The conclusion, when everything has been heard, is: fear God and keep His commandments, because this applies to every person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For God will bring every act to judgment, everything which is hidden, whether it is good or evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator
